block.p: United Airlines to Acquire US Airways for $4.3 Billion United Airlines plans to acquire US Airways for $4.3 billion in cash, creating a carrier that would have the largest share of passengers from Boston to New York to Washington.

The new airline, to be known as United, will have hubs in seven American cities and employ 145,000 people. If completed, the acquisition would be the first merger of two major American carriers since a wave of consolidation in the 1980's. [Page A1.]

A Ruse by Time Warner Employees Time Warner employees in Houston were offered a choice of free Internet service or the chance to win $100 by calling Southwestern Bell and placing an order for high-speed Internet service. If the order was confirmed, they were to cancel the service and report their results to an administrator. The ruse was apparently intended to find out precisely where the company was technically able to offer Internet service and exploit any weaknesses. Southwestern Bell says it will file complaints. [A1.]

Chase in Deal for Investment Firm Chase Manhattan has agreed to buy the Beacon Group, a private investment and advisory boutique founded in the early 1990's by former Goldman, Sachs deal makers. Terms were not disclosed. But Chase plans to name Beacon's founder, Geoffrey T. Boisi, a former Goldman banker, as head of investment banking, replacing James Bainbridge Lee Jr. [C2.]

Merck and Schering in Venture Merck and Schering-Plough said they were developing pills that would combine the biggest product of each company with a medicine from the other. The agreement allows the companies to work on a pill to combine Merck's asthma pill Singulair with Claritin. The companies will also try to combine an experimental Schering-Plough cholesterol drug with Merck's Zocor. Shares of Schering-Plough rose $1.625, to $45.4375, while those of Merck rose $1.375, to $73.6875. [C10.]

Panel Backs Merger of Exchanges The plan to merge the London and Frankfurt stock exchanges moved a step forward when the supervisory board of the German exchange voted to approve the deal. Deutsche Borse, parent of the Frankfurt stock exchange, said after the vote that the merger should be completed by the end of the year. [C4.]
Amex Names a New President The American Stock Exchange named Peter Quick, the former president and chief executive of the discount broker Quick & Reilly, to serve as president of the exchange. [C2.]

Flamingo and Fishing Fundamentals A. W. Dahlberg has many stories to tell about life in Georgia and his 40 years with the Southern Company, the electric utility that he now serves as chairman and chief executive. The stories start with a mule named Kate and continue through a ''great role model'' who threatened to fire Dahlberg at one point, a George Patton uniform, a gorilla suit, a pink flamingo, a couple of Harleys and aspirations of selling fishing licenses and worms. The Boss. [C9.]

Refunds Offered for Late Flights Biztravel.com, the Internet unit of Rosenbluth International, is offering travelers who book tickets through its site on any of five major airlines cash refunds if their flights arrive at the gate more than 30 minutes late. Joe Sharkey: Business Travel. [C10.]
Ameritrade Names Chief Executive Ameritrade Holding appointed Thomas K. Lewis Jr. as chief executive, succeeding J. Joe Ricketts, who remains chairman. [C2.]

Interpublic Revamps Marketing Unit Interpublic Group is stepping up its commitment to the fast-growing realm of specialized marketing services outside the scope of traditional advertising. Interpublic is reorganizing a division known as the Allied Communications Group, handling tasks for clients ranging from research to consulting to talent management. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C8.]
